4 troopships sunk | notes = }} {{Campaignbox Mediterranean Campaign}} The '''Battle of Skerki Bank''' was a [[World War II]] [[naval battle]] which took place near [[Skerki Bank]] in the [[Mediterranean Sea]] on the early hours of 2 December 1942 between [[United Kingdom|British]] and [[Kingdom of Italy (1861–1946)|Italian]] forces and was the last major naval battle in the Mediterranean during 1942. == Background == The British force consisted of the [[light cruiser]]s {{HMS|Aurora|12|6}}, {{HMS|Argonaut|61|2}} and {{HMS|Sirius|82|2}} with the destroyers {{HMS|Quentin|G78|6}} and {{HMAS|Quiberon|G81|6}}. The squadron was under the command of [[Rear Admiral]] [[C. H. J. Harcourt]]. On the night of 2 December, they found and attacked an Italian convoy and its escort bound for Tunisia. The convoy consisted of three destroyers and two [[torpedo boat]]s: the German ''KT-1'' (850 tons), ''Aventino'' (3,794 t), ''Puccini'' (2,422 t), and ''Aspromonte'' (an armed [[Ferry|ferry-boa]]t, 976 tons). The ships were carrying reinforcements for [[Erwin Rommel|General Rommel]]'s [[Africa Korps]]. It included 1,766 troops, 698 tons of cargo (mainly ammunition), 4 tanks, 32 other vehicles and 12 artillery pieces. The escort was composed of the destroyers {{ship|Italian destroyer|Nicoloso da Recco||2}} (flagship), ''[[Soldati-class destroyer|Camicia Nera]]'', ''[[Folgore-class destroyer|Folgore]]'' and the torpedo boats ''[[Spica-class torpedo boat|Clio]]'' and ''[[Orsa-class torpedo boat|Procione]]'' which were commanded by [[Captain (naval)|Captain]] [[Aldo Cocchia]]. == Battle == The British ships opened fire and destroyed all the cargo and troop ships. The escort ships were hit as well, with ''Folgore'' fatally damaged (nine 133 mm direct hits) by cruisers, and later sunk with 120 dead (among them, commander Ener Bettica), ''Nicoloso da Recco'' badly damaged (an explosion of the forward 120 mm ammunition magazines put her out of commission until June 1943) with 118 dead. ''Camicia Nera'' launched all her 6 torpedoes, which missed their targets. HMS ''Sirius'' escaped with no damage despite ''Camicia Nera'' firing on her from only {{convert|2|km}}, dodging several torpedoes and continued cooperating in the sinking of the Axis convoy. == Aftermath == At dawn, the short-range engagement saw a clear British victory, while the Axis suffered no fewer than 2,000 casualties (probably 2,037 or even 2,200, the total is uncertain) {{citation needed|date=December 2015}} and lost five ships, with ''Puccini'' still afloat, but to later sink. Whilst they were withdrawing [[SIAI-Marchetti|Savoias]] attacked Q-Force, without result but losing some aircraft. [[Supermarine Spitfire|Spitfires]] claimed four [[Savoia-Marchetti SM.79|Sparvieros]] with one loss, while HMS ''Quentin'' was sunk with 20 dead by a 500 kg bomb released from a [[Junkers Ju 88]] (the hit scored may have been a torpedo). On the other side, the human losses were 124 from ''Folgore'', 118 from ''Nicoloso da Recco'', 39 from ''Aspromonte'', 3 from ''Procione'', 200 civil/militarized crew and 1,527 troops, all in ''Aventino'' and ''Puccini''.Sgarlato, Nico: Lo scontro del banco di Skerki, Eserciti nella Storia magazine, Delta editions, Parma, gen-feb-2012, p.23-25 == External links == * [http://www.navweaps.com/index_oob/OOB_WWII_Mediterranean/OOB_WWII_Skerki-Bank.htm Convoy Battle near Skerki Bank] == References == {{Reflist}} {{coord|37|45|12|N|10|57|12|E|display=title}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Skerki Bank}} [[Category:1942 in Italy]] [[Category:Allied naval victories in the battle of the Mediterranean]] [[Category:Mediterranean convoys of World War II]] [[Category:Naval battles of World War II involving the United Kingdom|B]] [[Category:December 1942 events]]
